item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
About Us

Free Spirit is a brand-new church for people who want to be part of a community where people aren't all alike. We're trying a lot of experiments to find out how to bring people in different places together. We expect that the church will be made of small groups who meet in many different places. We're just beginning, so you can expect this page to change as we experiment.

You can check out our links for more specifics. If you have a question, a comment, or want to share some of your own story, you can fill out our contact form or chat.

item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
Free Spirit is a different church for different people.
We believe that the love of God, the life of Jesus, and the power of the Spirit are meant for everyone.
We are serious about building a community that allows each of us to be who we truly are.
We meet in small groups that build real relationships.

MEET US

item.title: Disciples of Christ
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
Disciples of Christ

Free Spirit Christian Church is part of a larger denomination called the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) or "Disciples."

The Disciples were started over 200 years ago by people who thought that Christians shouldn't have to be divided into many different churches. Today, we still believe that people who follow Jesus should be able to join together even if they don't act or think the same.

The Disciples don't have a list of beliefs that all churches have to accept or a specific way that worship has to be done, so each Disciples church will look and feel unique. However, Disciples celebrate communion at every worship service. Instead of being brought together by what we think, Disciples are brought together by what we do--joining together around the table to remember Jesus and come closer to him. When we have communion, everyone is invited to take part.

Disciples baptize people after they make their own confession of faith in Jesus. Normally we baptize by immersion. However, if you were baptized in another church or another way, you don't have to be baptized into the Disciples specifically. And if you can't be immersed in water, you can be baptized with water in another way.

Disciples have pastors, but we believe that all Christians can be leaders. Disciples churches normally have a group of elders who are responsible to guide each church. Communion and baptism are normally done by a pastor or elder, but we believe that any Christian can baptize someone or celebrate communion.

In 2000, the Disciples made a commitment to start 1000 new churches by 2020 and to become an anti-racist church. Free Spirit is part of both those commitments: we're one of the 1000 new churches and we're committed to being an anti-racist congregation.

item.title: About Alan_Old
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: If I were you, I'd want to know something about the person who's behind the website I'm reading. So here's a bit about me, what I believe, and what I'm doing. I read a lot of blurbs on web pages for church people. Most start with family, education and experience. So I wrote that, but I don't think any of that would help you to get to know me as a person. I suppose it makes sense to start with God. God has been so much a part of my life that I don't know how to explain it in any useful way. God has been with me through the best and the worst, loving me unconditionally no matter what--and there have been some "whats." I've been carried through ups and downs...not by my faith, because at times my faith has been pretty weak, but by God always being there no matter what. And knowing God was there, I couldn't do anything but take on this way of life--a way of life that is admittedly pretty weird. Weird is really the place to start. If you want to know what makes me who I am, the most basic fact is that for as long as I can remember, I've been completely unable to fit in. Even when I tried to be normal, I just couldn't manage it--at all. So I decided to embrace being abnormal, and that's worked pretty well for me. That means I don't worry very much about being judged by other people. I've always tried to be who I am and not who other people tell me to be. When I was a kid I thought that was the most important thing. But there's something more important--because I knew I was abnormal, I knew that I had to work hard to understand other people. And along the way, I discovered that everybody is different. We are all totally unique! That could be the best news you ever hear, but a lot of us have a hard time with it. And so I wanted to tell everyone that they were amazing and wonderful and should celebrate who they were made to be. Eventually I realized that it wasn't enough to tell people that they were amazing...I had to actually experience how amazing people were. I had to stop talking, start listening, and learn humility (that's a word you don't hear much anymore!) I'm probably never going to be a truly humble person, but I'm working on it--and I have learned a lot by listening to people who don't have any idea how wise they are. So that's what got me here. I want to be part of a community of people who listen to each other, who teach each other that they are important, who learn from each other. That's a pretty hard thing to find. You might even say it's not natural--and I'd agree with you. Our human nature seems to push us to block out people who are different, to quit listening, to stay safe. But I believe there's more to us than what we see in human nature. I believe in the supernatural--a power that lets us be more than we think we can be on our own.

item.title: What You'll Hear
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
What You'll Hear

This page is intended to help you understand what you'll hear if you hang around Free Spirit.

Free Spirit is built on Jesus. There are a lot of ways to approach spirituality and belief. There's wisdom in all of them, and potential for harm in all of them. Free Spirit is based on the spiritual path that's usually called Christianity.

Free Spirit and the things you'll hear from us are rooted in the Bible, the word of God. Although the Bible has special authority, we respect the wisdom of the Christians who have come before us and the lessons they've taught. Sometimes you'll hear old-fashioned words like salvation, sin, incarnation, Trinity, and more.

You'll hear about how we need to listen to each other and understand each other. Even though Free Spirit talks about the word of God, we know that God can't fit into words. So we have to recognize the difference between our words about God and who God really is.

You'll hear about God's love. The Bible says that God is love, and we work to show that love to all people. The Bible also says that love casts out fear, and you'll hear about how to overcome your own fears and how to help others be less afraid.

You'll hear about how we need and get forgiveness. We recognize people can be awful to each other and that we are capable of evil. You'll hear that there's no point in keeping score or comparing ourselves to each other to figure out who's better or worse.

You'll hear about true community. We believe in taking down the barriers that separate people from community. We are anti-racist. We believe in the full equality of women, men, and other genders.

You'll hear about wealth. The Bible spends a lot of time talking about how people with wealth should use it, and tells us that wealth is spiritually dangerous. By Biblical standards almost every American is wealthy, even though some are wealthier than others.

item.title: Why Another Church?
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: There are already about 338,000 churches in the United States. So anyone who thinks about adding another one has to be serious about asking the question—why do we need one more? Free Spirit is taking on one of the toughest challenges there is: building community among people who don’t have a lot in common. If you go to a church-starting class (and yes, that’s totally a thing), they’ll tell you to figure out who you’re trying to reach. Usually that means looking for a target demographic—people who are similar in terms of their ethnicity, age, wealth, or shared cultural experiences. We’re starting by throwing out demographics. The target group for Free Spirit is people who want to have a real community of people who aren’t all like them. Nobody really knows how to reach people like that, or how many people like that there are, or how to find them. So we’re going to have to try out lots of different things, experience many successes and failures, and learn about which tools work as we go. Since Free Spirit is doing something new, we’ll need to find a new way to do it. This will be an expedition into the unknown, a real adventure, and nobody knows how it’s going to turn out. And like any high-risk mission, the mission of Free Spirit requires volunteers…people who are ready to sign up for an experience that will challenge them, push them outside their comfort zone, and find out what they’re really made of. It wouldn’t be fair to drag people who are comfortable in their churches along on this voyage into the unknown—and they wouldn’t get far anyway. So we’re starting a new church, made up of people who are ready to be part of an experiment. At the base, that means playing with new ways of getting together. I hope that Free Spirit will be a church that exists in many places. Instead of expecting everyone to come to one room at a specific time on Sunday morning, Free Spirit will have many small gatherings of people in different places. So we’re not starting with a defined location. If the vision of Free Spirit speaks to you, there’s a way for you to be connected even if you’re not close to me or other people who are involved today. If you might want to join on this adventure, this is your chance! We have an email contact form, or you can chat (right now we’re not always available to chat, but if we can’t chat now, we’ll get back to you later today).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So, how can I stay. " in the loop?" I am relativel comfortable in my large (by Huntington standards) super conservative (even by Huntington standards) Mennolite light United Brethren denomination church. Especially since I have been taking a leadership roll outside my comfort zone. I am working with three others to start a series of mental health awareness support groups. I know this is small beans compared to what you are doing, but is huge for me and my church. There is no other church in Huntington County doing this. As much as possible in our 97% white Euro descent county we are trying for diversity. Not just in race and culture, but in all areas. The older I get, the more open I am becoming. I know..weird, right? Anyway...prayers for you and this venture, Alan. Next time you are in FW, it would be great to meet you and Jessica for coffee (or a glass of vino.)

Hi Linda! Thanks for the (very first) comment! I think mental health awareness is a hugely important issue. If I let myself get started, this comment will turn into a blog post! There's nothing small about anything related to mental health, and a series of groups in your area would be a big deal.
When you said Huntington County was 97% white I thought you were exaggerating...but I looked it up and, sure enough. If you look at church groups, you'll find that the ones with the strongest internal identity and structure (what you'd call "conservative") are often the best at being truly diverse: Anabaptists, Holiness churches, the Seventh-Day Adventists. I'm not a big fan of strict rules, but there's no question that sharing distinctive rules can help people make "Christian" a more important part of their identity than "white" or "middle-class" (which the Bible clearly tells us to do). So there's a lot of potential for a Mennonite light UB super-conservative church to move beyond barriers that are created by "the world." Maybe the first step (a very hard one) would be for people to recognize that Huntington County is 97% white on purpose.
Will definitely keep in touch! Thanks for connecting.

As a self-described "agnostic Christian" (formerly a Roman Catholic - even an Altar Boy at one point!) I find this kind of project interesting, and will be following the growth of your new Church. I think there is great potential for genuine Christian spirituality to make a positive difference in this troubled world of ours ... but sadly, I believe most established Christian Churches haven't done a great job in nurturing that spirituality, either within their congregations, or beyond.
I wish you the best of luck with your new Church!
Chris, that truly means a lot. We've never really talked about religion, and I am truly interested in hearing what you see as the missing pieces in genuine Christian spirituality.

item.title: Meet! Old
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
We'll share a bit to eat and drink and get to know each other. We'll start with introductions, share a bit about ourselves, reflect on Scripture, and decide what the next step is. Everyone will have an opportunity to participate, but no one will be required to speak. If we have a larger group, we will split up for part of the time so each person will have time to share and listen.
The cost for food and drink will be covered. If you'd like to come, please reply through the form below.

item.title: So What's the Bullshit?
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: One of the first recommendations for anyone starting a new group —a company, club, church, whatever—is to come up with a clear definition of what the group is about. This has seeped into the corporate world as the “mission statement.” Every organization has one, and many people even have “personal mission statements.” I’m not sold on mission statements, but a church does need to say what it’s about—and Free Spirit, is about Jesus without the bullshit. When I tested this line, some people looked pretty offended. And that’s OK—if you’re one of those people, it’s virtually certain that one of the 338,000 other churches in the US will be a good fit for you. Most people laughed, or said something like “that’s cool!” It got people’s attention. But nobody asked me the really important question—what is the bullshit that Free Spirit is doing without? Bullshit is all the stuff that leads us to hide our true selves. Each one of us is totally unique. Each person has experience and insight and power that no one else will ever have. Each of us has something to contribute to the world, to the people around us, that nobody else can give. Every one of us is different from everyone else. But being different comes with a cost. The world we live in doesn’t deal with different very well, and we’re all under a lot of pressure to fit in. The way the world pushes us into a box, and the way we pretend to fit into it—that’s bullshit. Free Spirit is designed to push back against that pressure. Free Spirit will be a community that helps you be honest with other people without fear. The world throws a lot of bullshit at us, but there’s a deeper level of bullshit—the bullshit we tell ourselves. Each of us has a picture of the kind of person we should be. We each have a box in our own minds that we try to fit ourselves into. That box is different for each person—the ideal self each of us imagines is as unique as the real self we actually are. But no matter what our goals are, no matter how hard we try to meet them, we all miss sometimes. And the pressure to fit into a box that comes from outside is nothing compared to the pressure that comes from inside. So Free Spirit works, even harder, to push back against that pressure. So Free Spirit will be a community that helps you be honest with yourself without fear. That’s a very simple introduction and if I were reading it I’d have a lot of questions…but that’s what comments are for! I’d love to hear yours.

item.title: Why Jesus?
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Why Jesus? That’s a good question, especially to ask someone like me. I believe that each person, no matter what they believe, has something to teach me about the world and about God. It’s pretty obvious to me that you don’t have to follow a particular religion to be an amazing person (or a terrible one). So why is it so important for me to call myself a Christian? Why is Jesus at the center of Free Spirit? Part of it has to do with Jesus’ teaching. The most radical statement of Jesus in the Bible is this: Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, so that you may be children of your Father in heaven; for he makes his sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the righteous and on the unrighteous. (Matthew 5:44-45) The statement “love your enemies” is very controversial. Many people reject Christianity because it tells people to love their enemies. That’s generous, because Christians have put a lot of energy into coming up with ways to avoid loving their enemies. But Jesus is even more radical when he explains why we should love our enemies. He says, “love your enemies because that’s what God does.” Jesus says straight up that God gives good things to people who don’t deserve them. That sounds great, but there’s another piece to it. If you don’t get in trouble for making the wrong choices, other people don’t get in trouble either. Your goodness don’t necessarily lead to a better outcome for your life. To put it even more simply: life is not fair. We have a hard time with this. We want fairness—we want everything to balance out. But think about a person who has truly loved you, who has made you feel safe. That relationship isn’t based on fairness and exchange—true love is unconditional and permanent. And the message of Jesus (and the rest of the Bible) is that God is love, and (as we all know) a loving relationship is better than a fair and balanced relationship. But it doesn’t stop with Jesus’ teaching, because Jesus isn’t known just for what he said—Jesus is known for his death and resurrection. The point of the story of Jesus’ death is that God directly experienced the suffering that human beings go through—all of it, even the experience of being alienated from God. The resurrection tells us that God’s power—the power of love—overcomes everything the world can throw at it. But the death of Jesus tells us that while God doesn’t make evil go away, God shares in the pain and suffering caused by the evil of the world.

item.title: Life Isn't Fair
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: In the last post I shared what I think is most radical about Jesus. He says that we're supposed to love our enemies. Why? Because that’s how God behaves. God gives good things to people who don’t deserve them. Now this sounds all warm and fuzzy—God loves everyone! Even more than that, God is actively doing good things for people. When Jesus talks about love, he’s talking about something that is practical and expressed in action. So when he says that God loves his enemies, he is saying that God is actively doing good things for people who hate and oppose him. But there’s another side to that which is harder to swallow. Jesus says that God is good to people no matter how they act. In other words, doing good things doesn’t increase the chances that good things will happen to you. Or to put it even more simply: life is not fair. This has the advantage of being based on reality. If you look at the state of the world, it’s obvious that there’s not a very strong link between doing good and getting good outcomes. Bad things happen to good people, and good things happen to bad people, and there’s no clear balance between the two. Life is not fair. We want to believe that life is going to be fair. This isn’t just a Christian thing—some people talk about karma, or the Rule of Three. But people want to believe that if you do good things, go things will come back to you somehow. In addition to creating fairness, it also puts us in control: we know that what we get is But it doesn’t seem to work that way in practice. Jesus here makes a radical statement that life is not fair. Even more than that, Jesus says that since God is in control, and life is not fair, then God doesn’t want life to be fair. For a lot of people, that seems like a contradiction of the most basic ideas about what God means: if God makes moral laws, and is supposed to enforce those laws, then shouldn’t God be there to make life fair? The answer, very simply, is no. After Jesus lived, one of his first followers wrote, "Love keeps no record of wrongs." Another one wrote "God is love." So we know that God doesn't keep a record of wrongs...God is forgiving. And forgiveness means that some people don't get what they deserve.

item.title: Is Heaven Fair?
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: When it comes to getting a good outcome in this life, there are dozens of passages that tell us that following Jesus isn’t going to lead to a life of comfort and peace. Probably the most famous example are the Beatitudes, where Jesus says that all the people you don’t want to be are blessed. They begin with: “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Most people—believers and unbelievers—read this a different kind of promise about the future. If you’re poor and meek and hungry here on earth, that’s a bummer, but don’t worry, because you’ll get rewarded in heaven. In that reading, Jesus is telling people who are suffering now to know that they’re getting a reward in heaven—their pain is a sort of investment in the future. For a lot of people, this is a selling point for Christianity—if you suffer now, you get a reward later. Supporters and attackers of Christianity have both started with the premise that Christianity is all about accepting pain now with the knowledge that you are getting a reward in the afterlife—a reward that you never see or experience, but which you have to have faith in. The power of this idea is obvious. If you think that you’re going to get an infinite reward that can never been seen or proven, you’ll be willing to do just about anything to get it. And there are lots of stories of people going through incredible suffering in the belief that they would go on to earn an eternal reward. Whether you find those stories inspiring or horrifying, they’ve had a powerful impact on the course of human history. But is that what Jesus really said? Jesus was really clear that life is not fair: sometimes good people suffer and evil people prosper. A lot of people see the idea of heaven and hell as a way to balance this out—the place where everyone gets what they really deserve. But later on Jesus tells another story. It takes about 4 minutes to read, but here’s the summary: Jesus says the kingdom of heaven is like a man who hires people to work all day in his vineyard. He agrees to pay them a fair wage for a full day’s work. Every few hours he finds new workers and offers them all the same pay. At the end of the day, the people who worked all day are mad because the people who only worked for an hour in the cool evening are getting the same wage they did for working all day through the heat. Jesus says that the landowner told one of them Friend, I am doing you no wrong; did you not agree with me for the usual daily wage? Take what belongs to you and go; I choose to give to this last the same as I give to you. Am I not allowed to do what I choose with what belongs to me? Or are you envious because I am generous?’ So the last will be first, and the first will be last. The landowner (God) doesn’t even bother to convince the first laborers that it’s OK for people to get different pay for the same work. Instead he just says, “am I not allowed to do what I choose with what belongs to me?” And then Jesus says, “so the last will be first, and the first will be last.” That couldn’t be more explicit. He says that the even in the “kingdom of heaven,” God doesn’t hand out good things in heaven based on what how much you suffered on earth. There’s no promise that everything will balance out. This might be upsetting. It leads to the question, “what’s the point of being good then?” Great question! But this is long enough for a blog post…so we’ll have to wait a bit to go on.

item.title: Why Be Good?
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I’ve always been a fan of Penn & Teller, who are stage magicians turned cultural critics. Penn was (is) the kind of person I relate to naturally—he has lot of opinions that he’s willing to back up in an argument, with a kind of awkwardness that doesn’t go away no matter how famous he becomes. Penn & Teller are famous skeptics and outspoken atheists, but Penn’s always made a distinction between religion (which he has big problems with) and religious people (who he can see as being good even when they’re terribly misguided). He recognizes that it’s important to listen to people who don’t share your beliefs. This is particularly relevant because--in the middle of a column where he says that all religion needs to go away forever--he says something that I completely agree with: Behaving morally because of a hope of reward or a fear of punishment is not morality. Morality is not bribery or threats. Religion is bribery and threats. Humans have morality. We don't need religion. This is one of the most persuasive arguments that atheists can make: if you're making moral decisions because you're looking for a reward from God, they're not really moral. No matter what, they're acting out of self-interest. A person who's trying to earn their way into heaven may look like they're selfless because they working for an invisible reward, but they're really only in it for themselves. When Jesus set aside the idea that what we get is based on a system of reward and punishment, he dealt with that argument. Jesus says, very clearly, that God loves good people and bad people and blesses them both. Jesus set aside the questions of reward and punishment that are so much a part of so many religions. He told his followers to stop worrying about getting a reward or avoiding punishment, and to recognize simply that each person is a beloved child of God. That has a lot of implications, but one of the most profound is that people who follow Jesus can be as moral as atheists. According to Jesus there is no bribery, there are no threats, there’s just a relationship with God who loves us as we are, leaving each of us to make moral choices by asking the simple question: who are you and who do you want to be?

item.title: The Power in Forgiveness
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Jesus was all about forgiveness. There’s a really short story about that in the Bible: Peter came and said to Jesus, “Lord, if my brother sins against me, how often should I forgive? As many as seven times?” Jesus said to him, “Not seven times, but, I tell you, seventy times seven times.” Jesus says: Forgive, forgive, forgive, again and again. It’s pretty clear, but there’s a problem. Anywhere you look, you can find people who use forgiveness as a way out. People who are assaulted and abused are told that they should forgive their attackers—adding an extra burden on people who have already been attacked. It’s a big problem for churches, but even people who have no connection to Jesus use “forgiveness” as a way to dodge the consequences of their actions. First we have to recognize that the problems of forgiveness are real. If you forgive someone, you’re giving up something you deserve—something intangible and powerful. Being wronged can take away the sense of safety, or an ability to trust, mental or physical health. And we understand at a very deep level that a person who takes those things from you owes you something…we even say that a person needs to “pay for their crimes.” So when you forgive a person who has wronged you, you’re giving up one more thing on top of what you’ve already lost. That’s hard, especially if you’re a person whose been “disempowered,” a person whose right to exist, whose basic humanity, is under attack—under attack, often, from the people who have wronged you. So we can’t sugarcoat it. When Jesus tells Peter that he should forgive, he’s telling Peter to give away some what he has to a person who has already robbed him already robbed him. And in today’s society (and every other society, ever) people who have power often take from those who don’t. So forgiveness often involves people with less giving some of what they have—not physical stuff, but something deeper—to people with more. How is that OK? You can find lots of stuff about forgiveness and how when you forgive, you’re really freeing yourself. People say things like, “being angry at someone just gives them power over you.” I’m not convinced by that. But I do know this—you can only forgive someone who sinned against you. I’m going to repeat that. You can only forgive someone who sinned against you. So when you offer forgiveness to a person, you are saying, absolutely, that what they did was wrong. You’re speaking a truth that people with power do not want to hear. When you forgive someone, you remind them that no matter how much power they have, they don’t have power over the truth. And you remind them that your freedom—to forgive or not forgive—is absolute. When we forgive, we are free and we speak the truth—and we remind a person who once had the power to hurt us that they can’t take control of us or of reality. That’s something people who seek power don’t want to hear.

item.title: They Couldn't Help It
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: For most of my life, I thought that “I forgive you” was the same as “you couldn't help it.” When I was lad at someone (which I hate), I would try to understand where they came from and what would lead them to behave badly. Then when I understood the forces that had shaped them to become the people they were, I could understand them, and say, “it’s OK—they couldn’t help it.” I thought that was forgiveness. I was wrong. I learned this gradually, but a key lesson came from working with people who had severe mental health issues. I was good at that job and became a manager, helping well-intentioned people help people with very serious issues—at least one major mental illness that was seriously impacting their life, but often two or three and regularly substance abuse too. We were there to help them get better. Our first rule was respect—to recognize that each person we worked with could and would make choices, and to respect those choices. It was hard to be respectful, because most of our clients didn’t have the tools to make good decisions. But it was hugely rewarding, because so many of our clients had rarely or never been treated with respect. And it was necessary, because changing requires a whole string of choices, made day by day, minute by minute. If we didn’t believe that our clients could make decisions on their own, we were wasting our time. I was surprised to learn that holding someone responsible is a vital part of respect. I got yelled at every couple of weeks, threatened a couple of times, and got grabbed once—all by people who known to have poor impulse control, a distorted view of reality and a history of trauma and abuse. They’d done these things before, and been brushed off with “they can’t help it.” But I was treating them like people who could make their own decisions. “They can’t help it” wasn’t an option—if our clients couldn’t help how they acted, then we were wasting their time. So I had tough conversations with people who did these things. And it turns out that they could help it. Nobody had an immediate or complete turnaround, but clients did make better decisions, got along better with others, achieved goals, and felt better. And at the core of it was the belief that they could get better. My job didn’t require me to forgive the clients who treated me badly, but I did—not because I believed that they couldn’t help what they did to me, but because I believed they could. So I realized that forgiveness is something much deeper than “they can’t help it.” It’s owning that a person really does have responsibility for what they did, and choosing to let go of it anyway. Forgiveness doesn’t erase responsibility—forgiveness can only exist when responsibility is there first.

item.title: Getting Forgiven Is Hard
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Forgiveness doesn’t erase responsibility—forgiveness can only exist when responsibility is there first. That was the end of my last blog post. And it helps to explain why we have a harder time with forgiveness than you’d think. Getting forgiven seems like the best thing ever. You do something wrong—which means that you’ve hurt someone, taken something away from them. You owe them. And they decide to let it go, so you don’t have to pay for what you did. Forgiveness is a gift you get from a person who has the right to take away what you already have. But…forgiveness follows from responsibility. If something was beyond your control, then you don’t need to be forgiven for it. So you can only experience forgiveness if you’re willing to accept responsibility for what you did in the first place. For many people, forgiveness is terribly threatening. Lots of people who harm others (maybe most) put a lot of energy into building worlds where their actions are right. People who oppress and abuse others don’t want forgiveness, because forgiveness reminds them that there’s a limit on their power. An old word for people who deny their need for forgiveness is “oppressor.” When one person attacks another, they’re committing a crime—it becomes oppression when the attacker claims the right to attack the other, to harm them. And forgiveness disintegrates the whole structure that oppression is built on. The minute an oppressor accepts forgiveness, they admit that they were doing wrong—and the whole structure that allows them to do what they want falls apart. This makes a person who offers forgiveness dangerous to oppressors. The person who offers their oppressor forgiveness is reminding their oppressor that they are doing wrong—that the whole structure they’ve built up to justify their actions rests on a lie. I believe that people know this. Everyone avoids the truth to some extent, and each one of us tries to put ourselves in boxes to keep out the truth we don’t want to deal with. But none of us can build a truly truth-proof box…wisps of truth always seep in. So when someone offers you forgiveness, they’re letting go of a claim they have on you—but they’re also taking a sledgehammer to the wall of your truth-proofing. And many of us would rather live inside the lie than get out of the box and face the truth.

item.title: War and Peace
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I made a decision, back when I was a teenager, that I wasn’t going to be a fighter. Even though I was a completely unassuming nerd, complete with huge glasses, I was angry and I didn’t want to unleash that anger on people around me. Not long after, I realized that I could do at least as much damage with my words and my ability to manipulate situations to my benefit, and I realized that “not fighting” required a lot more than just not hitting people. I’ve spent my whole life striving to be a man of peace, to build connections with others instead of fighting them. It’s still a work in progress, but I’ve never stopped trying. Years later, when I was a small-town minister, I worked to be active in the community. That got me involved in a lot of events that I wasn’t completely on board with, but never made a fuss (except once, but that’s another story). Being polite, and being the pastor of a fancy old downtown church, meant that I got invited to a lot of community events. And though I didn’t agree with everything I heard at all of them, I generally came away with new appreciation for the town I lived in and the people in it. But one stands out from all the rest. One of my friends had begun a second career as a pastor after retiring from the state police, and he did a lot. He put together an annual 9/11 memorial, organized events for first responders, and one year put together a community service whose featured speaker was a Marine Corps officer. I don’t remember a lot about it—not even what time of year it was for or what it was meant to commemorate. I don’t even remember what I said. But I do remember the speaker. He came in immaculate dress blues, shined and perfectly pressed. He was dignified and gracious—making sure that he brought credit to the people he was there to represent, which I understood. And when he talked about the military, he shared how he had a deep desire to help people, to protect innocents, to take on a burden that not everyone could. And then he quoted the words of Jesus: “ No one has greater love than this, to lay down one’s life for one’s friends.” And he said, “each person I served with, that’s why we were there—we were ready to lay down our lives: not to win a battle, not even to serve our country, but for each other and the people we loved.” Even now I get choked up when I think about the quiet intensity of his words. He was completely sincere: he was a warrior for some same reasons I’m not.

item.title: Finding Fault
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
When something bad happens, we want to know who’s to blame. We naturally believe that a person who harms another—the one who is to blame—should be the responsible for making the situation better. We feel this so strongly that when someone causes harm they can’t repay, we still want to see them “pay for their crimes” in ways that don’t really benefit anyone. Millions of people are employed in figuring out who is at fault for bad things—lawyers, investigators, claims adjusters, and more, all figuring out who must pay for hurt done to others.
Making people pay for the cost to fix a problem they caused does seem fair. But even in legal situations, there’s a lot of ambiguity. The people who are hurt don’t get back everything they lost, and often the people who did the most harm aren’t the ones who pay the most. Some people feel a sense of closure or justice when they see a person who hurt them being hurt back, even if it doesn’t actually bring back anything they lost. If justice means that everyone gets what they deserve, then it truly is just for a person who causes suffering to suffer in turn.
But…I’ve known lots of people who were abused and harmed by others—actually, I am a person who was abused and harmed by others. And as far as I know, every one of those people had been abused or harmed by someone else before they ever met me. I’m sure those people were harmed by others, and so on, and so on. The people who hurt me were all suffering long before I came into the picture. The pain I could cause them is nothing compared to the suffering they already experienced. And seeing that, making them pay isn’t so important.
This is why Jesus spent so much time talking about forgiveness. According to the Bible, our pain and suffering is rooted in choices that were made thousands of years ago, long before any of us were born. And all the scientific evidence we have tells us that the Bible is right about that—we are shaped more deeply by the pain and suffering of our ancestors than we ever understood, to the point that our biology is changed by what happened in previous generations. When you ask “who is to blame?” for any situation, the answer becomes an ever-deepening spiral that never hits bottom…with so many people who have given and received harm to each other that none of us could ever bring true justice out of that situation. And so Jesus tells us set all of it aside, to stop looking at the past and turn toward the future…to see what we can do with what we’ve been given.

item.title: Love Doesn't Keep Score
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I’ve said in earlier posts that the world isn’t fair. For a Christian, or most kinds of religious people, this may seem like a strange thing to say. There are lots of Christians who think of God as the person who makes everything fair, and suggesting that life isn’t fair is challenging to the way that many, perhaps most, Christians approach religion, God, and everything in life. There’s ample evidence that life isn’t fair all around us. Good things happen to bad people, and bad things happen to good people. But a lot of people will tell you that there’s a deeper level of fairness beneath what we can see. Some people talk about karma the Rule of Three—that bad things come back to bite you somehow. Other people say “everything happens for a reason,” that the bad things lead to greater good in a plan that’s bigger than we can see. Other people say that the imbalance in your life will affect you after you die. This last one includes a fair number of Christians, who will tell you that the good and evil you do in the world today will be rewarded or punished in the afterlife. Since Christianity teaches that God is good and just, it’s understandable that a lot of Christians think this way—that God will make everything fair. But if you dig into the Bible and into the teaching of Christianity over the centuries, it turns out that Christianity doesn’t teach that God makes life fair in some way. But if God doesn’t make life fair, what good is God then? How can God be good if God ultimately isn’t making everything fair? To start, let’s think about what fairness is. When something is fair, people get what they deserve. For two (or more) people who are cooperating or in a relationship, this means that what people get out should be based on what they put in: the more you put into a relationship, the more you should get out. But wait a second…if you think about the most important relationships in life, it will be clear that they don’t work when they’re defined by fairness. The relationships that matter the most—with family, with spouses, with lifelong friends—don’t work well when they’re based on fairness. It’s certainly true that many people do “keep score” in their family and marital relationships: there are plenty of examples of parents and children, brothers and sisters, husbands and wives, who get upset when they feel like they’re being unfairly burdened by their relationships. But if you talk to family counselors or psychologists—not religious people, just people who study mental health--you’ll hear them tell you that keeping score doesn’t build deeply meaningful and lasting relationships. It turns out that the deepest and most meaningful human relationships happen when people choose to support each other without keeping score, simply for the sake of the relationship itself. The most powerful relationships are built on love. This is why love is at the core of Christianity. Christians believe that everything in the universe exists because it’s in relationship with God—the deepest kind of relationship that it’s possible to have, a relationship based on love. Lots of religions believe that God or the gods love people, but Christianity goes a step further and says, God is love. God is love, and love doesn’t keep score.

item.title: Better Than Fairness
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
The idea that God doesn’t keep score isn’t easy for everyone to process. In part this is part of our nature. The urge to make things fair is deeply rooted in us—in fact, there are several animal species who recognize and care about fairness in multiple experiments. So our brains respond at a very primal level when we feel that something isn’t fair to us. We want to get our fair share!
Many of us have never experienced anything more than relationships based on fairness. Even as children, we’re taught that we have to earn what we get from other people. Many of us learn, from a very early age, that we have to earn what we need—food, comfort, kindness. We learn that there’s a cost to everything, and that the cost must be paid. Even when it comes to emotional support, we learn that we have to earn what we need.
In some cases, which our society today thankfully treats as unacceptable crimes, children have to earn their basic needs for food and shelter. But far more often, children learn that we have to earn comfort and affection. When a person hasn’t experienced that unconditional love, it’s very hard for them to grasp what it looks like. Like many things, it’s something you have to experience to understand—so a person who has never experienced unconditional love will never even realize that they’re missing something.
This has created a bizarre situation, where we use the word “love” to mean two totally different things. On the one hand, we use “love” to describe the unconditional love that’s at the root of our deepest relationships. On the other hand, we use “love” to describe conditional relationships between people who are trying to be close to each other. The use of same the word has gotten us confused, because there’s a complete difference between unconditional love and the “love” between two people who support each other based on their sense of fairness.
So naturally, when people who haven’t experienced actual unconditional love hear that “God is love,” they will get as close as they can—that God wants to make people feel good and makes everything fair. It’s possible, in fact, to read the whole Bible and construct your whole religious life around the idea that God’s goal is to make everything fair, to make things balance for everyone. And there are plenty of places where you can get a sort of version of Christianity that’s based on that conditional support that we call love but isn’t really. But the headline in the “good news” that Jesus told his followers to proclaim is that God’s love is totally unconditional, that God is love. We don’t get fairness—we get something much, much better.

item.title: Getting Serious
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: There haven’t been any posts to the blog for a week. Of course that has something to do with the time of year—I spent Thanksgiving really unplugged from work (including church work) and didn’t take much time to worry about what to do. But there was more to it than that—I wasn’t really satisfied with what I’d written and took a few days to reassess. I’m finally figuring out why communicating on the Internet is so difficult for people today. People want to feel connected to each other—so much so that I can feel it in the air. “Social media” is filled with people who are talking to each other, showing each other pieces of their lives, trying to feel like they have a connection with each other—and everywhere I look in the offline world, people are trying to find ways to be related to each other. And as someone who wants to bring people together, the best thing I can do is help people feel like they’re connected to me, by sharing enough of myself to let people feel like they really know me. But there’s this problem—it’s not supposed to be about me. When I was about 23, a friend of mine asked me why I was going to seminary and being part of a larger church. “You can just start the church of Alan!” she said. And I had a moment of insight: that’s exactly what it would be. That moment crystallized the importance, for me, of making sure that I never put myself at the center, of always pointing beyond myself. So talking about myself and helping people build a connection with me, somehow that feels wrong. But… But the Bible says that humans are created “in the image of God.” That means that if you want to see God, the best way to do that is to look at the people around you—and the more you see them, the more you see God. I really believe that, and that’s why I want to encourage people to see each other and to allow themselves to be seen. If you’re hiding who you are from the world, you’re hiding God from the world. But can I apply that to myself? We’ll see.

item.title: Getting Attention
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
In the last post I talked about the challenge of being more open and talking about spirituality rather than spiritual ideas—in other words, I started to think about I should talk more about myself and what I go through. Just saying that sounds weird, because Jesus said clearly that we shouldn’t draw attention to ourselves—right? Jesus said,
Be especially careful when you are trying to be good so that you don’t make a performance out of it. It might be good theater, but the God who made you won’t be applauding. When you do something for someone else, don’t call attention to yourself. You’ve seen them in action, I’m sure—‘playactors’ I call them—treating prayer meeting and street corner alike as a stage, acting compassionate as long as someone is watching, playing to the crowds. They get applause, true, but that’s all they get. When you help someone out, don’t think about how it looks. Just do it—quietly and unobtrusively. That is the way your God, who conceived you in love, working behind the scenes, helps you out.
But in literally the same speech, Jesus also said
We’re going public with this, as public as a city on a hill. If I make you light-bearers, you don’t think I’m going to hide you under a bucket, do you? I’m putting you on a light stand. Now that I’ve put you there on a hilltop, on a light stand—shine! Keep open house; be generous with your lives. By opening up to others, you’ll prompt people to open up with God, this generous Father in heaven.
So Jesus tells us to not call attention to ourselves, and also to shine so everyone can see us. How are we supposed to do those things at the same time? I think it ultimately depends on our goal. If we highlight ourselves because we want people to think about us, to praise us, to talk about how great we are—that’s self-centered. If we’re sharing about ourselves to point people to something beyond ourselves, that’s different. It’s about our motivation. That would be an easy solution if we could be sure of our motivations. But the truth is, there’s a mix of motivations in every one of us. We like to imagine that the line between good and evil is between us and them—but really, there’s a line between good and evil in each of us…and all too often it isn’t really a clear line, but some kind of mixed-up, blotchy, oil-and-vinegar compound that we can’t clearly separate. And there’s no way distill the good and the bad completely—they’re in each of us. There’s no rule or list of criteria that will get you to the answer.

item.title: Getting Real
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I’ve been sharing that when I thought about how I was communicating in this blog, I felt like I wasn’t really digging deep enough to do what needed to be done. I’ve been talking about ideas and beliefs, about principles, but not about myself. Obviously I’m not going to tell you everything. Nobody tells everything about their life in a blog, not even if they try. Words on a screen leave don’t communicate enough about a person to get you anywhere close to everything about them. And yet, it’s a great miracle that you get something about me from what I’m writing—maybe more than I ever intended. The pattern of light and dark you’re looking at somehow manages to carry meaning and a piece of me in it. But since I’m thinking about what I’m writing, how easy is it for me to make sure that you see what I want you to see? Everyone wants to see authenticity, to see a person who is being who they are. But the minute you start thinking about whether you’re being authentic, you’re already getting things complicated. If I think about whether I’m being authentic, am I as authentic as I would be if I just typed the first thing that popped into my head? And if I think of a better way to say something—a way that I like more—is that more me or less me if I change what I write? And what about doing things to convey a specific message? It’s so easy to get caught up in thinking about the message you’re sending rather than what you’re actually writing. This week I’ve tried to avoid that now by writing exactly what comes to mind and seeing what happens. I’m pretty sure that it sounds different from the things I’ve written before, but who knows if it’s better? You do...what do you think?

item.title: About Us...
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Free Spirit isn't alone...we're part of a larger church called the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). We have regional ministers who are there to support us. My regional minister, Rev. Eugene James, asked me to write something about the foundation of the church. I wrote this and I like it enough to share! Almost every Christian believes that the church should cross ethnic, class, geographical, and cultural boundaries, but almost every Christian goes to a church where they meet people who are mostly like them. We say, and even believe, that the Gospel is for all people, but most of us interact only with Christians who are pretty much like us. There are powerful forces deep in human minds and human society that create barriers to building community and fellowship between people who come from different histories and cultures. Free Spirit is founded on the belief that the Holy Spirit is more powerful than the barriers that separate us from each other, that Paul meant it when he said “there is no longer Jew or Greek, there is no longer slave or free, there is no longer male and female; for all of you are one in Christ Jesus” that Jesus meant it when he said “I will draw all people to myself,” that it’s not mere chance that those words are part of the word of God. Free Spirit is founded on the belief that separation and fear are not part of human nature. We are created in God’s image, to be at peace with each other, to be free from fear, to live with love. Each person has a deep yearning for that love, and Free Spirit will be a community where that love can be known—not because we imperfect humans can love each other perfectly, but because we can turn together to God whose love is perfect.

item.title: Without a Net
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
I tried something new a few days ago. I spent a few dollars on a Facebook ad that invited people to ask for prayer, and turned it on. And I waited.
It didn’t happen right away, but after a while people started to ask for prayer, or just to talk. And the things people needed prayer for, needed to talk about, were serious. Heart problems, kids having trouble, finding a job with a new degree, domestic violence, homesickness…talking to me about it, because I literally am paying for the chance to offer prayer for people. I put myself out there, and now I’m out there…far out there. And I’m reminded again of how terrifying it is to be doing this.
Ministry isn’t like most jobs. Most jobs have some measurable standard of success that helps you know whether you’re doing it right. Obviously numbers and statistics don’t capture everything there is about a job, but in other work, I’ve had at least some way to know whether I was doing it well or poorly. Ministry isn’t like that. Success in ministry defined by God—and God is notoriously difficult to pin down! Even when I to people and they go away feeling happier or better, that doesn’t necessarily mean that I’ve done what needed to be done. There’s ample evidence that I can’t rely on the approval of others to tell me that I’m doing ministry right. But I also can’t rely simply on my own opinion—ministers who make all their decisions based on what the Holy Spirit tells them are famously prone to getting far away from anything that is good for anyone.
And with all that uncertainty, I’ve had the gall to tell complete strangers that I’ll talk to God on their behalf. And some people are OK with that—they’re willing to let literally a random person on the Internet get involved in their relationship with God. There’s so much room for things to go wrong…and there I am.
But this is, literally, what I signed up for. I grabbed that trapeze and I’m swinging out over the unfathomable depths of our biggest questions—whether life has meaning, how we live with suffering, how we learn to love and be loved. And there’s no safety net...

item.title: You Were Created Good
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Who do you want to be? This is the question that Jesus confronts you with. Jesus presented his listeners with a remarkable proposition: God doesn’t have a set of rules for you. God doesn’t have a list of requirements that make you worthy. Instead, God offers unconditional love—love that continues no matter what you do, no matter what rules you follow. For a lot of people, it’s hard to associate Christianity with unconditional love, freedom, and transcending rules. A lot of time in Christianity is spent talking about how we should live, and about sin—the things that separate us from God, the things we do wrong. But if you dig in, God’s unconditional love, and the freedom that comes with unconditional love, makes it possible for us to talk about how we should live and how we fall short. Let’s start with one very basic fact: according to the Bible, people are naturally good. In the very first chapter of the Bible, there’s a story about the creation of the world. God forms plants, the sun and moon, sea animals, and earth creatures. After each one, God saw that it was good. Then God creates humans: So God created humankind in his image, in the image of God he created them;  male and female he created them. And at the end, God saw everything that he had made, and indeed, it was very good. In the Bible this is the starting point for understanding who and what humans are: we are created in the image of God, and we are part of a creation that is very good. The rest of the story doesn’t go quite as well. Soon after this story, the Bible tells us that the first humans broke with God and were introduced to suffering, labor, and death. The rest of the Bible is full of stories about humans treating each other badly and doing things that are wrong. Humans become separated from God and from the image of God within them—separated in ways that we can’t fix. But the separation from God (which the Bible calls “sin”) comes later. Separation from God, even the separation that’s unavoidable and part of the human existence we know, is unnatural. The spiritual center of every human is an image of God; the things that turn us away from God are additions. This means that for Christians, coming closer to God means coming closer to yourself. Learning about God means learning about yourself. Following God means following your true self. The process of spiritual growth, for Christians, isn’t about adding layers—it’s about removing the barriers within yourself that conceal your true spiritual core, the image of God, from the world. The closer we get to our true selves, the more truly and fully we are able to follow God.

item.title: Being in Control
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
I've been thinking about how easy it is to fall into the trap of seeking to control other people's feelings. Many of us try to get other people to feel a certain way about us. That's a waste of time.
Most of us have seen (and maybe experienced) this in romantic relationships. I think of a friend of mine who told me that she didn't think she could be a good girlfriend. She'd had a number of relationships and the women she dated had similar complaints—she wasn't attentive enough. They thought she should be texting in the morning, calling in the evening, and seeking out special opportunities to spend quality time together. My friend didn't want to do all that. She pushed herself to remember to call and keep in touch, but she's a busy person with an active live and it was hard to make that time. So, after dating a few people my friend decided she didn't did have what it took to maintain a serious relationship. You've seen the movie so you know what happens next. Literally the very minute she resolved to give up on dating, she met someone who she really clicked with. She gives her new girlfriend texts in the morning, calls in the evening, lots of time together...because she feels like it. All the affection she couldn't force herself to demonstrate in the past comes naturally now.
Maybe you’re wondering what this has to do with God…if so, check back in! I won’t even make you wait for days!

item.title: Feeling Some Kind of Way
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I've always taken comfort in something Jesus said: "You are blessed when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, because your reward in heaven is great. They persecuted the prophets who were before you in the same way." Jesus hit upon a truth that goes beyond Christianity—when you speak a truth people don't want to face, they often respond with resistance, anger, or even violence. This is so common that even Jesus could refer to ancient history for examples. For most of my life I used this insight of Jesus to justify saying things that people resisted. But over time I realized I had a problem. The truth can cause resistance and conflict, but so can a lot of other things. I've come to realize that sometimes people call me an asshole because I'm following Jesus, and sometimes they call me an asshole because I'm acting like one. I've learned there are people who get confused in the other direction—when someone calls them a jerk, they assume that means they've done something wrong. I still get a little confused when I talk to people like this. Sometimes a friend or co-worker will describe a situation where they worked really hard to be kind and generous, only  to be met with anger. They'd say, "that customer is mad at me." I'd listen and say, "it sounds like you couldn't do anything about their problem." They'd say, "no, I couldn't," like it was obvious. Then I'd ask, with genuine confusion, "so what's the problem?" I literally didn't understand that some people believe that it's their responsibility not to make people mad. Since part of my job is training people to do tech support, this caused me some problems. I literally didn't know that some of the people I trained would feel bad whenever a customer got mad at them, even if there was nothing they could do about it. Even if there was nothing they could do about it. You might think that people like me who try to get people mad are the opposite of people who try to keep everyone happy. But ultimately we have one thing in common—we are both trying to control the emotions of the people around us. We both live in a world where we are doing things with the goal of getting people to feel a certain way. Ultimately it doesn't matter what feelings we're trying to get out of people—once we set a goal of making someone else feel a certain way, we're screwed no matter what happens. Other people's feelings are not under our control. If we set out to make someone have a feeling and fail, we're disappointed. But that's actually better than success. That just builds up our illusion of being able to control other people. Worse yet, it builds up our sense of control over other people. The more we focus on getting other people to have feelings, the more thoroughly we move away from relationships of freedom and love that are the real foundation of happiness.

item.title: Thank you for calling customer support
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: Any conversation about feelings and expectations falls into romance, but the temptation to control people's feelings isn't limited to romantic relationships at all. Think about work—today, in the US at least, 80% of people work in "service industries." Almost everyone will have at least one job where they are supposed to do something for someone. Everything from cleaning a toilet to designing an app to performing a play is a service—the value of your work is on what you do for them, not in what you make. You'll find that many companies talk about making people happy. They say that they don't just want to provide a service, but they want to create a feeling among the people who use that service. In a general sense, you can do things that are likely to make people feel good. The company I work for answers computer questions. Part of my job is listening to angry customers who "want to speak to a manager." Keep in mind that 35% of people in the US admit to yelling at a customer service person, and 15% admit to swearing at one.  I talk to a lot of angry people,. And I've observed that the level of a customer's anger is only loosely tied to the severity of their problems. I've talked to people with very severe problems who were totally relaxed and pleasant, and people who were absolutely enraged about a problem that could be fixed in just a few minutes. In fact, the very angriest customers are the ones who want us to fix problems that they caused themselves. So I spend time reminding technicians that we don't have control over the feelings of our customers. Now that doesn't change our responsibility to do our best work. At one time, if you sent a question over email, you could expect a response in a few days. Now, you get a response in a few hours. Because of this, we have more happy customers than we used to. But when I'm talking about a complicated customer problem with a technician, I don't ask, "could you have made them happier?" I ask, "could you have done something to help them better?" Instead of looking at the uncontrollable (another person's feelings), we can look at what we can control (our behavior). For many of us it's hard to let go of the desire to control other people's feelings. Now you may be thinking that it's possible to get some success in generating feelings in other people—and that's true. But it turns out that in this case, success is even worse than failure.

item.title: The Cost of Control
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded: I've been talking about the danger of trying to control the feelings of another person. Even if you're trying to get another person to feel something good, even if you're trying to help them, setting out with the goal of getting another person to feel something is always always going to cause trouble. You might think that there's an obvious practical problem: emotion is incredibly complicated and you can't actually make a person feel anything. However, that's not really the root of the issue. While you can't control someone's feelings absolutely, you can take actions that are likely to generate feelings in other people. You can't push all the buttons all of the time, but you can push some buttons some of the time. The irony is that when it comes to controlling other people, success is even worse than failure. How can that be? To answer that question, think about your relationships with other people—friends, family, professional, romantic. There are people you have to be around, and people you want to be around. Or, to be more accurate, there are elements of requirement and choice in our relationships with everyone around us. When you think about the relationships that bring you the most joy, are they the ones mostly based in obligation or the ones mostly based in freedom? Everyone I've asked about this answers "freedom." Maybe it seems obvious that we find more joy in relationships we want to be in than the ones we have to be in, but we also find more joy in relationships when the other person genuinely wants to be there. I'll go out on a limb and say that there's nothing better than the experience of being with someone who is with you solely because they want to be there. Again, this goes beyond romantic relationships—there's nothing like being with someone who genuinely wants to be with you. Let me say that again: there's nothing like being with someone genuinely wants to be with you. Nothing. Every human being craves that experience, but you can only have that experience if the people around you are free to do what they want. The more control you control the people around you, the less you can experience the joy of being loved and appreciated just for who you are. When we control another person's feelings, we move the balance of the relationship from freedom to obligation. And that will cut us off from having any chance to have the relationships that really nourish our souls.

item.title: Fearfully and Wonderfully Made
item.dc:creator: freespiritcc
item.content:encoded:
I am fearfully and wonderfully made. This is a hugely popular Bible verse today…a reminder that each of us is created by God—that you are created by God. Our universe is larger than we can even begin to comprehend, and in it, you are unique and irreplaceable. Each one of us is fearfully and wonderfully made.

But...

We all have things we don’t like about ourselves, and we try to leave those out:

I am fearfully and wonderfully made, except for my hair.

I am fearfully and wonderfully made, except for my fat.

I am fearfully and wonderfully made, except for my mood swings.

That’s not what the Bible says about who we are…the writer of that psalm says, “I am fearfully and wonderfully made.” And that doesn’t leave anything out. There is nothing in you that is excluded from being fearfully and wonderfully made.

Now that gets a little complicated. Part of who we are is formed by what happens to us, and what happens to us is formed by other people who don’t always follow God’s will. Lots of us have been formed by traumatic experiences or losses, and I don’t mean to say at all that God intended for those traumas to happen. And I don’t believe that God created some people to struggle through life and some people to have it easy. But I do know that every living person lives because God has brought them through. I know God has a purpose for who we are today. I know God loves and cherishes each of us unconditionally—not just every person, but every bit of every person, all the things we love about ourselves and all the things we wish we could cast away. And to totally know and love God, we have to admit that God totally knows and loves us.

Because that line, we are fearfully and wonderfully made, isn’t even a whole verse. The whole verse is

I praise you because I am fearfully and wonderfully made; your works are wonderful, I know that full well.

When I say, “I am fearfully and wonderfully made,” I’m proclaiming that what God makes is good. And I, who God made, am good, just as I was made. So to praise God and love everything God has done, we have to include what God has done in us…all the messy, complicated ways that God has brought us to be who we are today.

Lord, I praise you because I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Your works are wonderful, I know that full well.
